headline: Moody's flags risk in Oracle's $300 billion of recently signed AI contracts
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -U.S. credit rating agency Moody's Ratings flagged several potential risks in Oracle Corp's $300 billion of recently signed artificial intelligence contracts, but stopped short of taking ratings action against the software giant.  Oracle said this month it expected booked revenue at its Oracle Cloud Infrastructure business to exceed half a trillion dollars.  The Wall Street Journal then reported that OpenAI had signed a contract to purchase $300 billion in computing power from Oracle over roughly five years, marking one of the biggest cloud contracts ever signed.

raw.headline: Moody's flags risk in Oracle's $300 billion of recently signed AI contracts

Oracle said this month it expected booked revenue at its Oracle Cloud Infrastructure business to exceed half a trillion dollars.  The Wall Street Journal then reported that OpenAI had signed a contract to purchase $300 billion in computing power from Oracle over roughly five years, marking one of the biggest cloud contracts ever signed.

headline: Broadcom (AVGO) Stock Trades Down, Here Is Why
summary: Shares of fabless chip and software maker Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) fell 3.3% in the morning session after a broader pullback sparked by reports that China banned its major tech firms from buying U.S. artificial intelligence chips. The negative sentiment weighed heavily on the Nasdaq, with the news first hitting chipmaker Nvidia and then rippling out to drag down fellow tech giants, including Broadcom.

headline: Oracle is Not in a Bubble, say Jefferies Analyst
summary: Oracle is part of the consortium set to keep TikTok running in the US. The stock has been soaring on earnings and AI deals. It's risen so fast that some analysts are warning of a bubble. But Jefferies' Brent Thill isn't worried. He has a buy rating on Oracle with a $360 price target. He joined Bloomberg Open Interest with Matt Miller and Dani Burger.

headline: Centroid Systems and Stellar Cyber Partner to Launch Advanced Managed Security Services for Oracle Customers
summary: SAN JOSE, Calif., September 17, 2025--Stellar Cyber, a leading provider of cybersecurity solutions and services, and Centroid Systems, LLC ("Centroid"), a leading provider of cloud services and technology solutions, today announced a strategic partnership to deliver cutting-edge managed security service provider (MSSP) offerings running on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI).

headline: AI Weekly: OpenAI makes a deal, Oracle makes waves
summary: STORY: From OpenAI getting one step closer to making money, to how Oracle made Wall Street take notice, this is AI Weekly.:: AI Weekly:: MicrosoftMicrosoft and OpenAI have struck a deal to restructure their relationship.Though the details aren’t set in stone, that should clear the way for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit firm.OpenAI wants more freedom to work with other firms besides Microsoft, which has been its main backer.:: MicrosoftBut the Windows maker wants to make sure it keeps access to the startup’s AI tech.Nvidia’s latest chips for the Chinese market seem to be getting a lukewarm response.Reuters sources say some major tech firms there have opted not to place orders.They say the new chip is seen as expensive for what it does.And they say performance lags older models that the U.S. has banned for sale in China, but which are readily available through grey market channels.:: OracleOracle has gone from AI laggard to potential champion.Shares in the firm surged after it gave a bullish outlook for sales related to the new tech, while the Wall Street Journal says it has a $300 billion deal just with OpenAI.GLOBALT Investments partner Keith Buchanan says the numbers made Wall Street take notice:"The sheer magnitude of just how quickly they've been able to get up the curve and also show it through commitments on the other side is what the big surprise was.” Donald Trump hit London for a state visit, with the two sides agreeing an AI-focused tech deal to mark the event.That will see top US firms invest billions in the country to help drive the new tech.Among other projects, Microsoft said it would spend around $30 billion to expand AI and cloud infrastructure in the UK, while also helping to build the country’s biggest AI supercomputer.And AI has wildlife experts puzzled.Researchers used the tech to estimate the number of wildebeest in Africa’s so-called Great Migration.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangThe bots looked at satellite images, and counted 600,000 of the animals, or less than half the number usually cited.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangNow the question is whether wildebeest numbers are really falling, or if one of the two estimates is way out.

to restructure their relationship.Though the details aren’t set in stone, that should clear the way for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit firm.OpenAI wants more freedom to work with other firms besides Microsoft, which has been its main backer.:: MicrosoftBut the Windows maker wants to make sure it keeps access to the startup’s AI tech.Nvidia’s latest chips for the Chinese market seem to be getting a lukewarm response.Reuters sources say some major tech firms there have opted not to place orders.They say the new chip is seen as expensive for what it does.And they say performance lags older models that the U.S. has banned for sale in China, but which are readily available through grey market channels.:: OracleOracle has gone from AI laggard to potential champion.Shares in the firm surged after it gave a bullish outlook for sales related to the new tech, while the Wall Street Journal says it has a $300 billion deal just with OpenAI.GLOBALT Investments partner Keith Buchanan says the numbers made Wall Street take notice:"The sheer magnitude of just how quickly they've been able to get up the curve and also show it through commitments on the other side is what the big surprise was.” Donald Trump hit London for a state visit, with the two sides agreeing an AI-focused tech deal to mark the event.That will see top US firms invest billions in the country to help drive the new tech.Among other projects, Microsoft said it would spend around $30 billion to expand AI and cloud infrastructure in the UK, while also helping to build the country’s biggest AI supercomputer.And AI has wildlife experts puzzled.Researchers used the tech to estimate the number of wildebeest in Africa’s so-called Great Migration.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangThe bots looked at satellite images, and counted 600,000 of the animals, or less than half the number usually cited.:: Maxar Technologies / Tiejun WangNow the question is whether wildebeest numbers are really falling, or if one of the two estimates is way out.

headline: Trump, China's Xi to discuss TikTok deal. What is the app worth?
summary: In their latest round of trade negotiations, US and Chinese officials reached an agreement this week on a preliminary framework for the sale of the popular social media app TikTok. President Trump and China's President Xi Jinping will further discuss the deal on a call. Cloud service provider Oracle (ORCL) — which hosts TikTok — is a frontrunner to acquire the app. Morning Brief host Julie Hyman reports the latest news and breaks down TikTok's estimated valuation in the US. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Fed decision, China's Nvidia ban, TikTok deal: 3 Things
summary: US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are largely flat as Wall Street awaits the Federal Reserve's latest interest rate decision coming out of its policy meeting later today. Experts anticipate Fed officials to cut rates by 25 basis points for the first time in 2025. China is banning companies from buying AI chips from major semiconductor manufacturer Nvidia (NVDA), according to Financial Times reports. Following fresh trade negotiations between the US and China, the latter has agreed to a deal framework for selling TikTok. Hear what Wire China editor Andrew Peaple has to say about US-China trade talks in regards to Nvidia, TikTok, and more. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: U.S.-China TikTok Deal Is a Cash Flow Story for Oracle. Here’s Why.
summary: Oracle  likely will remain the cloud computing provider for TikTok, the social media app run by China-based ByteDance, in a deal that provides an important plank of financial support as the tech giant ramps up spending on its artificial-intelligence-focused strategy.  The Wall Street Journal reported that  Oracle  along with private-equity group Silver Lake and venture-capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, will own 80% of the U.S.-based operations of TikTok under the proposed deal, which could be concluded this week.  The stock has added more than $700 billion in market value since the autumn of 2022, shortly after it first began routing TikTok’s U.S. data through Project Texas, which was created to address concerns that TikTok’s user data would be collected and held by China-based entities.

raw.headline: U.S.-China TikTok Deal Is a Cash Flow Story for Oracle. Here’s Why.

The Wall Street Journal reported that  Oracle  along with private-equity group Silver Lake and venture-capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, will own 80% of the U.S.-based operations of TikTok under the proposed deal, which could be concluded this week.  The stock has added more than $700 billion in market value since the autumn of 2022, shortly after it first began routing TikTok’s U.S. data through Project Texas, which was created to address concerns that TikTok’s user data would be collected and held by China-based entities.

headline: Oracle Sparks Bubble Talk With Stock Price in Dot-Com Territory
summary: Shares of the database software company have soared 84% this year, the seventh-best performance in the S&P 500 Index, as scorching demand for AI computing turbocharges its revenue growth.  Oracle also has been linked to the Trump administration’s negotiations to keep TikTok operating in the US.  The company has served as TikTok’s primary cloud infrastructure provider for years.

headline: Heard on the Street Tuesday Recap: The Fed’s in a Tight Spot
summary: The Dow industrials, S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite all fell, despite some decent gains by megacap names like Amazon, Meta and Tesla.  Suspense is building ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest-rate decision.  Stronger retail sales may complicate the case for numerous rate cuts if central bankers believe inflation is still a risk.
